text: now in recent weeks
much of our attentions been focused on
the events in Syria with the Syrian
conflict on their minds Americans are
asking an age-old question are we an
isolationist country that doesn't want
to get involved in other nations
problems or are we a global leader who
must try to solve them Charles Lindbergh
the great aviator was also America's
most famous isolationist in the years
leading up to World War two Lindbergh
gave fiery speeches across the nation
insisting that we stay out of the
European war that was being fought
President Franklin D Roosevelt was
afraid of Lindbergh Roosevelt was
convinced the United States must
intervene in World War two then Pearl
Harbor became America was now at war and
there was no longer a debate about
whether or not we should be fighting
isolationism emerged again in the early
1950s when war broke out in Korea
scourging the place with napalm
isolationists left and right a post
American intervention in that conflict
and also the broader cold war against
the Soviet Union in this period
isolationism gave way to unilateralism
this was the idea that America was
involved in the greater world but on our
terms alone during the Vietnam War
period
it was liberals who were often labeled
isolationists in 1972 the Democratic
Party nominee George McGovern said there
were more important battles to fight
in the United States than overseas
I'm home America today after more than
10 years of war in Iraq and Afghanistan
isolationist sentiment is strong in both
parties Americans are tired of war
